{"title":"page 45","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"ty, to take the dying declaration of the person, or
to give such directions in the premises as he may
consider necessary.
Sec. 21. In case of an alarm of fire, the police
officers who arrive first at the scene of conflagration, must be particular to note the exact location
of the fire, and must examine minutely to ascertain
if there is any appearance of the house, store or
out-house having been set on fire by design. They
must note on their memorandum books the situation and place of particular kinis of goods, and
every thing that they may observe that could be of
service, in case the origin of the fire should become
a matter of legal investigation.
Sec. 22. Whenever any fire shall happen in
the night, the policemen shall give notice to each
of the firemen and policemen who may be at their
homes within their respective beats ; and they shall
also give the alarm by crying " Fire," and by
springing their rattles.
Sec. 23. The policemen will endeavor to clear
the streets from crowds and obstructions, so that
there shall be sufficient space for the firemen to
perform their duties, and a place for the deposit
of property saved.","fullrs":{},"find":"2684.jp2","dmaccess":{},"dmimage":{},"dmcreated":"2012-01-18","dmmodified":"2012-01-18","dmoclcno":{},"dmrecord":"2683","restrictionCode":"1","cdmfilesize":"468077","cdmfilesizeformatted":"0.45 MB","cdmprintpdf":"0","cdmhasocr":"1","cdmisnewspaper":"0"}
